abstracts.cdata!:
The Decentralization Adjustment Loan
            (DAL) will support the Government of Mexico in bringing
            market-driven order and accountability to the country's
            rapidly moving decentralization process. In particular, the
            DAL will support four immediate policy objectives - imposing
            hard budget constraints on federal resources, provided to
            states and municipalities; reducing moral hazard in
            sub-national borrowing; increasing transparency and public
            accountability of sub-national fiscal, and financial
            management; and, setting pilot mechanisms to enhance
            efficiency in decentralized expenditures, with an emphasis
            on health, and environment related issues. The DAL will be
            disbursed in two tranches, and implemented within the
            context of an ongoing International Monetary Fund Stand-by
            operation, and parallel financing from the Inter-American
            Development Bank. However, several risks may hinder success,
            given the difficulties in obtaining consensus for the
            necessary reforms, following the upcoming elections,
            including the possibility of refusal, from some
            states/municipalities, in adopting what may be viewed, as
            imposition. But while financial-sector related technical
            difficulties may also threaten program objectives, the
            project design placed an emphasis on avoiding the need for
            legislative action.
